RE: [junit] Best practice with EJBImplement the important things in normal
java classes. You can test those easily with JUnit.
The EJB should be only a very THIN facade into this java package. The EJB
doesn't do anything by itself, it only redirects the client requests.
This way, it's still important that you test the EJBs, preferebly in such a
way as Robert describes, but you can do most of the work by simply running
simple JUnit tests on normal classes, without having to deploy anything.


  -----Original Message-----
  From: Robert Watkins [mailto:robertw@...]
  Sent: dinsdag 3 april 2001 0:30
  To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
  Subject: RE: [junit] Best practice with EJB


  Ralf Krakowski writes:
  > Hi,
  > I wonder if there is a preferd way to use JUnit with EJB in
  > your opinion?
  > What is best practice and have anyone used any extensions like JUnitEE
  > (http://www.infohazard.org/junitee/) or j2eeunit
  > (http://j2eeunit.sourceforge.net/)?

  The various extensions to JUnit do not test EJBs. They test servlets,
which may in turn talk to EJBs. Personally, I find this distasteful. My
major objection to it is that, with most EJB servers (including WebLogic),
having to repackage and redeploy EJBs to run the tests just takes too long.

  What I do is write my tests like this:

  public void testSomething()

    MyObject obj = obtainMyObject();
    ...
  }

  obtainMyObject() is a "smart" function. When running in 'live' mode, it
obtains a JNDI context and retrieves the EJB remote interface. When running
in 'local' mode, it returns an instance of the EJB class directly. So I have
the same batch of tests running in a local mode and a non-local mode.

  This makes my life a lot easier. My test cycle is a lot shorter, and that
makes me feel good. My "local" tests don't give me 100% confidence; the
local version has no security, no transactions, nor anything else provided
by the container. However, it gives me about 90% confidence that my business
logic works. Then, when I run the test in 'live' mode (which I do as part of
my integration work), I get the extra 10%.

  > Any tips regarding using Visual Cafe and Weblogic 6 with
  > junit would be
  > great.

  Yeah; don't use Visual Cafe. :)

  I plan to write up a proper paper on this subject at some point (assuming
I get a round tuit, of course).

  Robert.
